body.p: We the undersigned, who were on the Jury, who tried W G Yancey for the crime of Larceny, most respectfully petition your Excellency to pardon him The verdict we rendered was for one years confinement in the penetentiary the shortest time fixed by law --
We think his case is one that peculiarly commends itself to executive clemency,

It was proved on the trial that he was very much intoxicated when he took the coat with of which he was charged with stealing, & we hope that you will pardon -- He is a young man without fortune, family or friends --

Respectfully
John W Conly
W. S Elam
Beverley Bourne
A H Talbott
J. Cernet
W. H. Hancock
E. H. Lewis
David Laura
A. W. Haskins
P Van Bussum
James H Farley
A J. Goode
I was the only witness by whom the taking of the coat was proved, & I join in the above application to your excellency, respectfully asking that you may will pardon W. G. Yancey --

Henderon Cir. Ct
1 yr Penty
Grand Larceny
W. G. Yancy
Pardon Issd June 19th 1862

To His Excellency
B Magoffin
Frankfort Ky
